choices.text: 90 degrees, with current leading the voltage.
90 degrees, with voltage leading the current.

choices.text: Unwanted, momentary switching transient at the output.
An error in the truth table.
A violation of the clock cycle.

questions.text: A 'Master-Slave' flip-flop is designed to:

choices.text: Eliminate the problem of race conditions.

questions.text: What is an 'opcode' in the context of a microprocessor instruction?

choices.text: The data to be operated on.
The part of the instruction that specifies the operation to be performed.

questions.text: Asynchronous serial transmission uses start and stop bits for:

choices.text: Synchronizing the receiver with the incoming data stream

questions.text: In C, what is a 'null pointer'?

choices.text: A pointer that has not been initialized.
A pointer that points to a memory location with the value zero.
A special pointer value that indicates it is not pointing to any valid object.
A pointer to a character string.

questions.text: What is 'operator overloading' in C++?

choices.text: The process of giving a special meaning to an operator for a user-defined data type.
Creating too many operators in a program.
The process of hiding operators from a derived class.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the try-catch block in C++?

choices.text: To handle exceptions or runtime errors in a controlled manner.

questions.text: A 'branch prediction' unit in a modern CPU is used to:

choices.text: Predict whether a conditional branch will be taken or not taken to avoid pipeline stalls.
Predict the result of an arithmetic operation.
Predict which data will be needed from memory.

questions.text: In the memory hierarchy, which type of memory is volatile?
A 'semaphore' is a synchronization primitive that consists of:

choices.text: An integer value and two atomic operations (wait and signal).
A reference to a shared memory segment.

questions.text: The process of adding a header and a trailer to data at each layer of the OSI model is called:
What is the primary purpose of the 'sliding window' protocol in TCP?

choices.text: To provide flow control and reliable data transfer.

What is the 'language of a grammar' G?

choices.text: The set of all production rules in G.
The set of all terminal symbols in G.
The set of all strings that can be derived from the start symbol of G.
The set of all non-terminal symbols in G.

choices.text: Tracing the path of light from the viewer's eye back through pixels into the scene.

choices.text: Number of nodes in the tree.
Length of the longest path from the root to a leaf.

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of Insertion Sort for nearly sorted lists?

choices.text: It has a time complexity of O(n).
It is faster than Quick Sort.

questions.text: 'Serializability' of transactions in a database system ensures that:

choices.text: The outcome of concurrently executing transactions is the same as if they were executed in some serial order.
All transactions are executed in parallel.

questions.text: What is a 'context switch' in an operating system?

choices.text: The process of switching the CPU from executing one process or thread to another.
The operating system changing its current directory.

questions.text: What is 'smoke testing'?

choices.text: A detailed and exhaustive testing of a software component.
A preliminary testing to reveal simple failures severe enough to reject a prospective software release.

questions.text: A 'Unified Modeling Language' (UML) diagram that shows the flow of control from one activity to another is the:
What is a 'design pattern' in object-oriented software engineering?

choices.text: A reusable solution to a commonly occurring problem within a given context.

questions.text: In a 'client-server' architectural style:

choices.text: A server provides resources or services to clients upon request.
The system is decomposed into independent, communicating components.
There is a centralized data store.

questions.text: The A* search algorithm is both complete and optimal if its heuristic is:
'Natural Language Understanding' (NLU) is a subtopic of NLP that deals with:

choices.text: Machine reading comprehension to convert text into a structured representation.

questions.text: The 'learning rate' in a neural network training process controls:

choices.text: The number of neurons in the network.
How much the weights are adjusted with respect to the loss gradient.
The total number of training epochs.
The type of activation function used.

questions.text: In engineering economics, an 'opportunity cost' is the:

choices.text: Actual cost incurred on a project.
Potential benefit that is given up when one alternative is selected over another.
Cost of a project's raw materials.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of a 'kick-off meeting' in project management?

choices.text: To formally start the project and align the stakeholders and team members.

questions.text: Which of the following is a role of a 'Project Sponsor'?

choices.text: To manage the project on a day-to-day basis.
To provide the financial resources and high-level support for the project.
To perform the technical work of the project.

questions.text: Ethical 'competence' for an engineer means:

choices.text: Only undertaking assignments for which they are qualified by education or experience.
Working longer hours than other engineers.

questions.text: The Nepal Engineering Council (NEC) is composed of members from:

choices.text: A mix of government representatives, professional engineers, and university faculty.

questions.text: The power dissipated in a purely resistive circuit is given by:
A Zener breakdown occurs in a diode that is:

choices.text: Heavily doped and has a thin depletion region.
Lightly doped and has a wide depletion region.

choices.text: A Moore machine's output depends only on the current state, while a Mealy machine's output depends on the current state and input.
A Mealy machine is more powerful than a Moore machine.
A Moore machine cannot have a final state.
A Mealy machine uses a stack.

questions.text: Topological sorting is an algorithm for ordering the vertices of a:
In C++, a virtual function is a member function that you expect to be:

choices.text: Called only from the base class.

questions.text: 'Cross-validation' is a technique in machine learning used to:

choices.text: Assess how the results of a statistical analysis will generalize to an independent dataset.

questions.text: A 'project charter' is a document that:

choices.text: Is created at the end of the project.
Formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply resources.

questions.text: The 'rms' value of an alternating current is significant because it:

choices.text: Gives the equivalent DC current that would produce the same heating effect.

What is a 'pointer to a function' in C?

choices.text: A variable that stores the memory address of a function.
A function that returns a pointer.
A synonym for a function call.
This is not a valid concept in C.

questions.text: 'Belady's Anomaly' is a phenomenon where:

choices.text: Increasing the number of page frames results in an increase in the number of page faults for some page replacement algorithms.

questions.text: The purpose of the ping utility is to:

choices.text: Test the reachability of a host on an IP network and measure the round-trip time.

questions.text: An 'undecidable problem' is a problem for which:

choices.text: It is impossible to construct an algorithm that always leads to a correct yes-or-no answer.
The problem has not yet been solved.

questions.text: In agile development, a 'user story' is a(n):

choices.text: Informal, natural language description of one or more features of a software system written from the perspective of an end user.

questions.text: A 'heuristic' is admissible if it:

choices.text: Never overestimates the cost to reach the goal.
Is based on a mathematical proof.

questions.text: 'Scope creep' in project management refers to:

choices.text: The project finishing ahead of schedule.
Uncontrolled changes or continuous growth in a project's scope.
A reduction in the project's scope.

In the context of agile development, what is a 'product backlog'?

choices.text: A list of all bugs found in the product.
A prioritized list of features, requirements, and improvements for the product.
The final documentation for the product.
